elements.title: Trial Progression Timeline: Visual Mapping of the Road of Trials
elements.problem: Campbell's Road of Trials is defined by recursion -- 'again, again, and again' (line 429) -- but the visual treatment of active_lease stays currently presents them as a flat, undifferentiated list. Each stay card looks identical: same styling, same weight, same visual presence. This produces what Campbell warns against: the hero loses sight of the wonderful land because each trial blurs into the next. The guest cannot see their own progression. The user stories document identifies that the guest's accumulated history -- 'reviews, familiarity with how things work' -- is a valuable asset, but the visual system does not render this asset as a visible arc. The result is visual monotony that maps to emotional monotony: the guest's 10th stay looks exactly like their 1st, which contradicts the reality that the guest is more confident, more competent, and more established by stay 10.
elements.solution: Design a horizontal timeline component where each stay is a node, and the visual treatment of each node reflects its status. (1) Completed stays: filled circles in accent (#2d5a3d), connected by a solid line in accent-light (#e8f0eb). Each filled circle is a dragon slain. (2) Current stay: a larger, pulsing circle in accent-bright (#3a7a52) with a subtle shadow-md glow. This is the dragon currently being faced. (3) Future stays: outlined circles in border (#e2dfd9), connected by a dashed line. These are the dragons yet to come. (4) Milestone stays (stay 3, stay 6, final stay): slightly larger nodes with an inner marker, accompanied by a brief label ('First month,' 'Halfway,' 'Final stay'). These are Campbell's 'momentary glimpses of the wonderful land.' (5) The overall visual arc should move left-to-right, with completed stays gently receding (smaller opacity) and the current stay in full visual focus. The timeline lives at the top of the stay dashboard, providing instant orientation before any detail is consumed.

evidence.quote: Dragons have now to be slain and surprising barriers passed -- again, again, and again. Meanwhile there will be a multitude of preliminary victories, unretainable ecstasies, and momentary glimpses of the wonderful land.
evidence.insight: The filled-vs-outline visual distinction between completed and future stays is the visual translation of 'preliminary victories.' Each filled circle IS a slain dragon. The milestone markers are the 'momentary glimpses.' The visual system must make the guest feel that they are moving forward on a road, not standing still in a loop.

evidence.quote: An experienced guest applying to a new host is cross-activation in action. Their history, their reviews, their familiarity with how things work -- it all reduces the host's anxiety.
evidence.insight: The visual timeline is the guest's own cross-activation credential rendered for their own consumption. When they see 8 filled circles behind them, they see their own competence. This visual record becomes the emotional foundation for the transformation credential that future hosts will see.

evidence.quote: The hero discovers and assimilates his opposite either by swallowing it or by being swallowed. One by one the resistances are broken.
evidence.insight: The visual progression from outlined (resistance not yet faced) to filled (resistance broken) mirrors Campbell's 'one by one' assimilation. The guest does not break all resistances at once -- they break them stay by stay, and the timeline makes this incremental victory visible.

colors: accent-light (#e8f0eb) for connecting line and timeline background
typography: mono (IBM Plex Mono) at 14px font-weight 600 for stay count indicator
spacing: sm (8px) between node and milestone label
new_tokens_needed: --timeline-node-completed: alias for accent, semantic token for completed trial markers
--timeline-node-active: alias for accent-bright with pulse animation keyframe

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: accent (#2d5a3d) on surface (#ffffff) achieves approximately 7.2:1 contrast -- exceeds AA. accent-bright (#3a7a52) on surface achieves approximately 5.3:1 -- passes AA. ink-soft (#4a4640) on surface achieves approximately 7.9:1 -- exceeds AA. border (#e2dfd9) on surface is decorative (future stay outlines), not content-bearing, so no minimum applies. Milestone labels use ink-soft on surface, well above AA threshold.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye finds the current-stay node first (largest, brightest, animated). Then it traces leftward to see the completed arc (filled, connected). Then rightward to see what remains (outlined, dashed). The stay count indicator (mono typography) provides precise numerical orientation. The overall read is: position first, history second, future third.
elements.brand_alignment: The green accent palette for progression aligns with the design system's use of accent for positive, growth-oriented signals. The timeline's clean, node-based design reflects the taste principle of 'confident, not flashy' -- it communicates progression through structure, not decoration. The mono typography for the stay count signals precision and reliability, reinforcing the evidence register established in the design system.

elements.title: Counter-Offer Warmth: Person-First Visual Treatment for Negotiation
elements.problem: The counter-offer screen is the visual moment where the guest meets the goddess face-to-face. Campbell describes how the goddess can appear 'terrible and benign' simultaneously (line 627) -- and the counter-offer IS this dual revelation. Changed terms are the 'terrible' face (the guest's desired arrangement is altered). The host's willingness to engage is the 'benign' face (the host cared enough to counter rather than decline). The visual treatment determines which face the guest sees first. A ledger-style presentation (old terms crossed out, new terms in bold) foregrounds the terrible. A person-centric presentation (host photo, message, engagement signals) foregrounds the benign. Campbell's insight that the goddess is 'redeemed by the eyes of understanding' (line 673) demands that the visual system give the guest 'eyes of understanding' -- a visual frame that presents the host as a person before the terms as numbers.
elements.solution: Design the counter-offer surface with a warm, person-forward visual hierarchy. (1) Top zone: host avatar (48px, rounded-full, bordered with accent-light #e8f0eb) beside host name in serif (Instrument Serif) at 18px. Below: the host's attached note in sans (Outfit) at 14px ink (#1a1a1a) on surface-warm (#fdfcfa). If no note, show engagement signal in ink-muted: 'Responded in 4 hours.' This zone uses warm background (surface-warm) with rounded container (radius-lg: 16px) and shadow-sm. (2) Middle zone: term comparison on bg (#f6f4f0). Original terms in ink-muted (#8a857e), proposed terms in ink (#1a1a1a) at font-weight 600. Changed values use accent (#2d5a3d) text, not signal-danger red. Each changed term has a one-line contextual note in ink-soft (#4a4640) at 12px. Connecting line between old and new uses border (#e2dfd9), not a strikethrough (which reads as rejection). (3) Bottom zone: three equal-weight response buttons. 'Accept' in accent (#2d5a3d) filled. 'Suggest different terms' in outline. 'Message [Host Name]' in outline with a message icon. All three are visually equal in weight -- messaging is not a secondary action.

evidence.quote: The temple image displayed the divinity in her two aspects simultaneously, the terrible and the benign. Her four arms exhibited the symbols of her universal power: the upper left hand brandishing a bloody saber... the upper right was lifted in the 'fear not' gesture, the lower extended in bestowal of boons.
evidence.insight: The counter-offer surface must display both aspects simultaneously without letting the terrible dominate. The host avatar and note are the 'fear not' gesture; the changed terms are the saber. The visual hierarchy must ensure the 'fear not' gesture (top zone, warm background, larger visual weight) is perceived before the saber (middle zone, neutral background, smaller visual weight).

evidence.source: user-stories-initial-analysis.md, 'Messaging is the highest cross-activation story' section
evidence.quote: When a guest messages a host, that's not just UX convenience -- it's the moment two strangers begin to trust each other through the platform.
evidence.insight: The 'Message [Host Name]' button must carry equal visual weight to 'Accept' because messaging during negotiation IS the trust-building mechanism. Visually subordinating it (smaller, grayed out, positioned last) would signal that the platform values transaction over relationship -- the opposite of what the Campbell lens prescribes.

evidence.quote: 'Let me have water, woman!' he cried. 'I will give it,' said she, 'and bestow on me a kiss.' He answered: 'forby giving thee a kiss, I will even hug thee!'
evidence.insight: Niall could embrace the hag because he saw her as a person worthy of engagement. The warm visual treatment of the counter-offer (serif typography for the host name, rounded avatar, surface-warm background) is the platform's mechanism for helping the guest see the host as worthy of embrace -- not as an adversary imposing unfavorable terms.

colors: accent (#2d5a3d) for changed-value text and accept button
accent-light (#e8f0eb) for avatar border and accept button hover
border (#e2dfd9) for term comparison connecting lines
typography: serif (Instrument Serif) at 18px for host name
sans (Outfit) at 14px for host note and term labels
mono (IBM Plex Mono) at 16px font-weight 600 for financial figures
spacing: lg (24px) padding inside host zone container
xl (40px) between host zone and term zone
new_tokens_needed: --counter-offer-host-bg: alias for surface-warm, semantic token for person-forward zones in negotiation contexts

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: ink (#1a1a1a) on surface-warm (#fdfcfa) achieves approximately 16:1 -- exceeds AAA. ink-muted (#8a857e) on bg (#f6f4f0) achieves approximately 3.2:1 -- below AA for body text, acceptable for de-emphasized original terms (supporting, not primary content). Must ensure original terms are also available at AA contrast if the user needs to read them (tooltip or expandable view). accent (#2d5a3d) on surface (#ffffff) achieves approximately 7.2:1 -- exceeds AA for the accept button.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye finds the host's face first (largest visual element in the top zone, warm background draws attention). Then reads the host's note or engagement signal. Then scans the term comparison for specific changes. Then finds the response buttons. The visual flow is: person --> message --> terms --> action. This is the opposite of the typical form-response pattern (terms --> action) and is deliberate.
elements.brand_alignment: The serif typography for the host's name signals warmth and personality, consistent with the taste model's prescription of 'serif for personality.' The accent green for changed values (instead of red) aligns with the brand's philosophy of positive, growth-oriented signaling -- even changed terms are framed as adjustments, not losses. The three equal-weight response buttons reflect the design principle of 'confident, not flashy' -- no button dominates because the platform trusts the guest to make the right choice.

elements.title: Gate Notification Cards: Structured Descent Visual System for Move-In
elements.problem: The seven-gate move-in orientation (L2, communicates-001) requires a visual language that communicates structured progression -- each notification is a gate in Inanna's descent. Currently, platform notifications use a single visual template regardless of context: the same card style for a marketing message, a date change alert, and a move-in orientation message. This visual uniformity means the guest cannot distinguish the sacred rites of the descent from ordinary platform communication. Campbell's gatekeeper declares 'Extraordinarily have the decrees of the nether world been perfected. Do not question the rites' (lines 354-356) -- the visual system must convey this gravity without creating anxiety.
elements.solution: Create a distinct gate notification card used exclusively for the seven-gate move-in sequence. (1) Container: radius-lg (16px), bg-deep (#eae7e1) background with a 2px left border in accent (#2d5a3d). This distinguishes gate cards from standard notifications (which use surface #ffffff). The warm, slightly deeper background signals 'this is part of your orientation, not a routine message.' (2) Gate number: displayed as a small pill ('Gate 1 of 7') in ink-ghost (#bdb8b0) at 11px mono (IBM Plex Mono). This provides positional context without competing for attention. (3) Gate title: in serif (Instrument Serif) at 16px ink (#1a1a1a). Examples: 'Your Neighborhood,' 'Getting In,' 'Top House Rules.' (4) Gate content: in sans (Outfit) at 14px ink-soft (#4a4640), limited to 3-4 lines. A single actionable link ('View full House Manual') uses accent (#2d5a3d). (5) Gate completion: once the guest has viewed the gate content, the left border shifts from accent to accent-light (#e8f0eb) and the gate number pill shows a small checkmark. The progression from gate 1 to gate 7 is a visual descent -- each gate slightly refining the card's appearance as the guest approaches the space.

evidence.quote: Upon her entering the first gate, the shugurra, the 'crown of the plain' of her head, was removed. 'What, pray, is this?' 'Extraordinarily, O Inanna, have the decrees of the nether world been perfected, O Inanna, do not question the rites of the nether world.'
evidence.insight: Each gate card IS a gate. The consistent visual template (same container, same structure, sequential numbering) communicates that this is a rite -- a deliberate, structured process, not random notifications. The gate number pill ('Gate 3 of 7') is the gatekeeper's announcement of position in the descent.

evidence.quote: Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.
evidence.insight: Each gate card shows useful information (neighborhood context, access logistics, house rules) before asking for anything. The visual design reflects this: content dominates the card, with any action (arrival confirmation, check-in prompt) positioned as a secondary element below the value delivery.

evidence.quote: This is the second stage of the Way, that of the 'purification of the self,' when the senses are 'cleansed and humbled,' and the energies and interests 'concentrated upon transcendental things.'
evidence.insight: The gate cards are instruments of purification -- each one strips a layer of uncertainty and concentrates the guest's attention on the immediate reality of the space. The visual restraint of the card (limited text, warm background, no decorative elements) mirrors this purification: no noise, only signal.

colors: accent (#2d5a3d) for active left border and action link
typography: mono (IBM Plex Mono) at 11px for gate number pill
serif (Instrument Serif) at 16px for gate title
spacing: md (16px) between gate title and content
sm (8px) between gate number pill and title
new_tokens_needed: --gate-card-bg: alias for bg-deep, semantic token for orientation-sequence cards
--gate-border-active: alias for accent at 2px, left border for current/upcoming gates
--gate-border-complete: alias for accent-light at 2px, left border for viewed gates

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: ink (#1a1a1a) on bg-deep (#eae7e1) achieves approximately 12.6:1 -- exceeds AAA. ink-soft (#4a4640) on bg-deep achieves approximately 5.1:1 -- passes AA. ink-ghost (#bdb8b0) on bg-deep achieves approximately 2.1:1 -- below AA, but gate number pill is supplementary positional context, not primary content. Accent (#2d5a3d) on bg-deep achieves approximately 5.8:1 -- passes AA for action links.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye finds the left border first (color accent draws attention to the card edge). Then the gate title (serif, largest text). Then the content (sans, body text). The gate number pill is perceived peripherally -- it provides positional context without demanding focus. The overall read is: 'this is an orientation message' (border) --> 'about this topic' (title) --> 'here is what you need to know' (content).
elements.brand_alignment: The bg-deep background connects gate cards to the platform's warm, earthy tone palette while distinguishing them from standard surface-white cards. The accent left border uses the green that signals positive progression throughout the design system. The serif title typography brings personality to what could feel like procedural notifications, aligning with the taste model's 'warm, not cold' principle.

elements.title: Cleaning Photo Ritual Frame: Evidence of Honorable Trial Completion
elements.problem: Cleaning photo submission is one of the most important per-stay rituals, but it currently looks and feels like a generic file upload. The guest drags or taps to upload photos, and the photos appear in a standard grid. There is no visual distinction between uploading cleaning photos and uploading any other file on any other platform. Campbell describes how the hero, after each trial on the Road of Trials, emerges with evidence of victory -- the golden fleece, the water from the well, the sorted grains. These are ritual objects, not file attachments. The cleaning photos are the guest's proof that they have treated the host's space with respect -- the equivalent of Campbell's hero presenting the trophy. If the visual treatment is indistinguishable from a tax return upload, the ritual meaning is lost, and the guest experiences the act as compliance rather than honor.
elements.solution: Design the cleaning photo submission as a visually distinct ritual frame. (1) Container: a card with surface (#ffffff) background, radius-lg (16px), shadow-md for elevation above the standard dashboard surface. The header reads 'Show Your Space Is Ready' in serif (Instrument Serif) at 16px, reinforcing the ritual register. (2) Photo grid: rounded-md (10px) corners on each photo thumbnail. When all expected photos are uploaded (minimum 3), a subtle completion indicator appears: a checkmark in accent (#2d5a3d) with the label 'Complete' in mono (IBM Plex Mono) at 12px. (3) Pre-upload state: the grid shows placeholder outlines with gentle labels -- 'Kitchen,' 'Bedroom,' 'Common area' -- guiding the guest to document the spaces that matter. Each placeholder uses border (#e2dfd9) dashed outline with ink-ghost (#bdb8b0) label. (4) Post-upload state: photos fill the grid with a subtle accent-light (#e8f0eb) border indicating acceptance. The card's overall background shifts from surface to surface-warm (#fdfcfa) once all photos are submitted, signaling ritual completion. (5) The timestamp is displayed in mono (IBM Plex Mono) at 11px, anchoring the ritual to a specific moment -- this trial was completed at this time.

evidence.quote: Psyche was aided by an army of ants... Venus told her next to gather the golden wool of certain dangerous wild sheep... An eagle approached and accomplished the marvelous task... Psyche was ordered, finally, to bring from the abyss of the underworld a box full of supernatural beauty.
evidence.insight: Each of Psyche's tasks required her to bring back physical evidence: sorted grains, golden wool, water, a box of beauty. Cleaning photos are the guest's equivalent -- physical evidence brought back from the trial of the stay. The visual frame must honor this evidence as meaningful, not reduce it to an upload form.

evidence.quote: A well-structured proposal -- clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent -- activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction.
evidence.insight: Extended to cleaning photos: well-structured, clearly labeled photos activate the host's trust (the space is cared for). Vague, unlabeled, or missing photos create friction. The guided placeholder labels ('Kitchen,' 'Bedroom,' 'Common area') ensure every photo submission is structured and activating.

evidence.quote: The hero discovers and assimilates his opposite either by swallowing it or by being swallowed. One by one the resistances are broken.
evidence.insight: The cleaning photo ritual is the moment where the guest demonstrates they have 'assimilated their opposite' -- they have lived in someone else's space and treated it as their own. The visual completion state (warm background, checkmark, accent border) marks this assimilation, distinguishing it from mere task completion.

typography: serif (Instrument Serif) at 16px for card header
mono (IBM Plex Mono) at 12px for completion indicator
mono (IBM Plex Mono) at 11px for timestamp
spacing: md (16px) gap between photo grid items
sm (8px) between header and supporting text
new_tokens_needed: --ritual-card-complete-bg: alias for surface-warm, applied when a ritual action (cleaning photos, arrival confirmation) is fully completed

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: ink (#1a1a1a) on surface (#ffffff) = 16.1:1, exceeds AAA. accent (#2d5a3d) on surface = 7.2:1, exceeds AA. ink-ghost (#bdb8b0) on surface = 2.8:1, below AA but acceptable for placeholder labels (supplementary, not primary content). Mono completion text at 12px uses accent on surface, which passes AA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye finds the header first ('Show Your Space Is Ready' in serif). Then scans the photo grid for completion status. The completion checkmark and timestamp provide confirmation. The overall visual arc is: ritual name --> evidence --> confirmation. Post-completion, the warm background shift signals at a glance that this ritual is done.
elements.brand_alignment: The elevated card (shadow-md) distinguishes the cleaning ritual from standard dashboard content, signaling its importance without being heavy-handed. The serif header brings ritual gravity to what could feel like a mundane upload task. The accent green for completion aligns with the progression visual language established in the timeline (looks-001), creating a consistent 'trial completed' signal across all active-lease surfaces.

elements.title: Goddess Transfiguration: Progressive Host Avatar Enhancement Across Phases
elements.problem: Campbell describes how 'the form of the goddess undergoes for the hero a series of transfigurations' (lines 664-665). In the guest journey, the host's visual representation should undergo a parallel transfiguration -- from icon to person to relationship. But the host's avatar currently appears identically across all phases: the same circular photo at the same size in the same context. In listing evaluation, the host is an abstraction; in active_lease, the host is a lived relationship. The visual system does not reflect this deepening. The goddess 'reduced to inferior states' by 'deficient eyes' (line 671) is the host reduced to a static thumbnail by a visual system that does not evolve.
elements.solution: Design a progressive avatar system where the host's visual presence deepens across phases. (1) Listing evaluation: standard avatar -- 40px circle, radius-full (9999px), single photo, name below in sans (Outfit) at 14px. The host is an icon. (2) Negotiation: enhanced avatar -- 48px circle with accent-light (#e8f0eb) ring border indicating active engagement. Name in serif (Instrument Serif) at 16px. Response time badge below in mono (IBM Plex Mono) at 11px. The host is a dialogue partner. (3) Move-in: contextualized avatar -- 56px circle, same accent-light ring, accompanied by a 'Your Host' label in ink-muted (#8a857e) at 12px sans. Below: communication channel indicator (message icon). The host is a guide. (4) Active lease: relational avatar -- 48px circle (returns to standard size for dashboard integration) with a stay-interaction indicator: a small dot showing recent communication status (accent for 'active in last 24h,' ink-ghost for 'no recent activity'). The host is a relationship. The progressive system ensures the host's visual presence grows with the guest's knowledge, never remaining frozen.

evidence.quote: As he progresses in the slow initiation which is life, the form of the goddess undergoes for him a series of transfigurations... By deficient eyes she is reduced to inferior states; by the evil eye of ignorance she is spellbound to banality and ugliness. But she is redeemed by the eyes of understanding.
evidence.insight: The avatar system IS the 'eyes' through which the guest sees the host. A static avatar system is 'deficient eyes' that spell-bind the host to banality. The progressive system provides 'eyes of understanding' -- each phase reveals more of the host as a person, redeeming them from the flatness of a listing-page thumbnail.

evidence.quote: Verified reviews and host credibility signals activate guests. A skeptical guest who sees verified reviews, ID checks, and real host history doesn't need the platform to convince them -- another user already did.
evidence.insight: The avatar enhancement at negotiation phase (engagement ring, response time badge) is a credibility signal made visual. The guest sees not just the host's face but their engagement behavior, and this visual evidence contributes to the trust-building that the user stories identify as critical.

evidence.quote: The remembered image is not only benign, however; for the 'bad' mother too -- (1) the absent, unattainable mother; (2) the hampering, forbidding, punishing mother; (3) the mother who would hold to herself the growing child -- persists in the hidden land.
evidence.insight: The active-lease communication status dot addresses the four aspects: an accent dot shows the benign, present host. An ink-ghost dot shows the absent host. The visual system does not judge -- it reflects reality, allowing the guest to see the host clearly rather than projecting.

ink-ghost (#bdb8b0) for inactive communication status dot
typography: sans (Outfit) at 14px for listing-evaluation host name
serif (Instrument Serif) at 16px for negotiation host name
sans (Outfit) at 12px for 'Your Host' label at move-in
mono (IBM Plex Mono) at 11px for response time badge

--avatar-status-active: alias for accent at 8px dot, indicating recent host communication
--avatar-status-idle: alias for ink-ghost at 8px dot, indicating no recent host activity

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: all name typography uses ink (#1a1a1a) on surface (#ffffff), achieving 16.1:1. ink-muted on surface achieves approximately 4.6:1 -- passes AA for supplementary labels at 12px+. The communication status dots are semantic indicators supported by additional context (tooltips or labels), not relying solely on color.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: At every phase, the host's face is the first thing perceived (largest, most visually distinct element). The surrounding enhancements (ring, badge, label, status dot) add layers of meaning that the guest absorbs after recognizing the face. The transfiguration is felt as 'I keep seeing the same person, but I understand them better each time.'
elements.brand_alignment: The progressive avatar system reflects the design system's principle of 'trustworthy, not corporate' -- it uses subtle, human-centric enhancements (ring borders, communication dots) rather than badges or labels that feel institutional. The serif typography at negotiation phase elevates the host's name to the personality register, signaling that the relationship has moved beyond the transactional.
